Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research, IPY: A Cooperative Arctic Data and Information Service (CADIS)
Award.AbstractNarration:
Proposal Title: Collaborative Research, IPY: A Cooperative Arctic Data and Information Service (CADIS)
Institution: University of Colorado at Boulder
Abstract date: 12/19/06

Barry: 0632296

This project will develop a Cooperative Arctic Data and Information Service (CADIS) that will support the Arctic Observing Network (AON) and Study of Environmental Arctic Change (SEARCH) programs. CADIS will provide the discovery, access, and use of scientific data by providing near-real-time data delivery, a repository for data storage, a portal for the discovery, and tools to manipulate data. This system and data service will be built in a stepwise coherent manner and result in comprehensive long-term management for Arctic scientific data. CADIS will be a joint effort of the University Corporation for Atmospheric Research (UCAR), the National Snow and Ice Data Center (NSIDC), and the National Center for Atmospheric Research (NCAR). The project team will develop a new body of cyberinfrastructure by leveraging, integrating, and extending UCAR's Community Data Portal (CDP) framework and Unidata's THREDDS environment to form the CADIS system and portal. The CADIS portal will make it easier for scientists to locate, display, subset, publish, and analyze related data sets provided by a network of data providers. In the first year, a metadata plan will be completed; it will include AON projects and Long Term Observatory (LTO) projects. In the second year, the CADIS portal will be populated with metadata from the AON and LTO projects. In the third year, real-time delivery through CADIS of selected AON and IASOA (International Arctic System for Observing the Atmosphere) data will be accomplished, and tools for searching via a map interface, and a map server showing the location of selected AON or SEARCH components (where metadata are available) will be added. Also in the third year, system performance will be evaluated and documented, and a future direction charted. Guidance from the scientific and lay user communities will be key to implementing the CADIS facility. Information will be received via questionnaires, meetings, standing committees and individual queries to assess CADIS effectiveness and recommend improvements. This project is highly relevant to International Polar Year goals for developing comprehensive data management plans and creating legacy data sets. The intellectual merit lies in the stepwise development of a new cyberinfrastructure for management of Arctic scientific data. The broader impact of CADIS is that it creates a foundation for long-term access to data archives, discovery, delivery and analysis by the Arctic science community and other users.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Arctic Observing Network (AON) is a group of about 40 investigations aimed at advancing observations of Arctic environmental conditions. In 2007, the National Science Foundation funded the National Snow and Ice Data Center (NSIDC), the National Center for Atmospheric Research (NCAR), and the University Corporation for Atmospheric Research (UCAR) to develop the Cooperative Arctic Data and Information Service (CADIS) for data from the nascent network of funded investigators.   Through the CADIS portal (http://www.aoncadis.org/) AON investigators can upload their data and write metadata describing it, and anyone can use the CADIS portal to look for AON data. CADIS safely archives AON data for future researchers.    Figure 1 is a schematic of CADIS.  Figure 2 shows some AON investigation sites on one of three maps views (one can also use Google Earth or a traditional GIS).

 

The most significant lasting accomplishment of CADIS may be the metadata authoring tool.  Metadata are a collection of words that describe data in a standard format.  If a data set has good metadata, it is easier to find those data, using search engines or data portals, even if one does not know that that particular collection of data exists.   Usually, a data center like NSIDC, the NOAA national data centers, or NCAR has specialists write metadata for data sets. This can be inefficient, however.   CADIS developed the metadata authoring tool to be a more cost effective solution for NSF’s arctic data.   Figure 3 is a screenshot of the CADIS metadata authoring tool as it would appear to an investigator entering metadata. 

 

AON was envisioned as “…a system of atmospheric, land- and ocean-based environmental monitoring capabilities--from ocean buoys to satellites--that will significantly advance our observations of Arctic environmental conditions”.  Its data service was envisioned as a portal through which scientists can archive their data and thereby meet NSF sponsor obligations; can find all data relevant to a location or process; can browse imagery and complete documentation; may plot online time series or fields; and can query multiple datasets and sources (see the Data Management chapter of the Polar Research Board’s 2006 report, Toward an Integrated Arctic Observing Network).  Some implications of these envisioned features were that all data have metadata at a detailed level (often called granule, file, or inventory level metadata in contrast to collection level metadata), stored in a relational database, and that data are in a standard format.   NSIDC, NCAR, and UCAR began the CADIS development project well aware of the insurmountable nature of some of the challenges involved but anxious to make progress. A talk on AON at the 2008 American Meteorological Society annual meeting (The Arctic Observing Network and its Data Management Challenges, available from http://nsidc.org/cgi-bin/publications/pub_list.pl) outlined the challenges and our anticipated approach. We faced multidisciplinary data in many formats, a diversity of archiving and access needs, and visionary investigator expectations. At the outset, we planned to leverage other cyberinfrastructure and enterprise data management interoperability efforts that were underway in disciplines like biodiversity and geosciences.
